SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid.
SP.P: Heyday!—Do you know whom you're talking to?
Yes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid
SP.P: Fie, fie, Sir!—Teach a girl to insult her mother.
Fie, fie, Madam—Teach a girl to desert her father!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol. [turning her towards him]
SP.P: Where are the letters Mandeville wrote from India?
Where is the money he sent for my support?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid.
SP.P: Peace! you little insolent!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol. [turning her.]
SP.P: Where is the agreement between you and the Tutor?
Where are a parent's affections—a so∣ver's heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid
SP.P: Silence!—or I'll so chastise you—

You chastise me!—The threats of my father or Mr. Howard would frighten me; because they're good people, and injured people; and if you had behaved well, I had been still afraid of you. But now—Oh! I wish I had a rod, I'd pay you off old scores, that's what I would I—Come, Sir Solomon, let's leave her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Aye: let us seek out the wronged, the honest Mr. Maddeville!

He's not to be found!—Mandeville's not to be found; and I shall not only lose my two hundred pounds,
but shall also be tricked out of my annuity—For yonder's Mr. Howard running about like a madman; and he swears, if he don't find him he'll put an end to his existence!— [Sees Albina.] Oh, ho!—Now we shall get information!—Your servant, Miss—or rather Master, Albina!
Sir!
Who's Governess now?—Didn't I tell you last night this lady was my mistress?
You did.
And isn't she—isn't she my mistress!

If you like it.—If you prefer serving her to me.—I'm sure I've no objection.—So I give you warning, and appoint the Game-keeper your successor.—Copsley shall be Steward to the young lady—Mr. Realize to the old one.
Copsley become Steward!—Why, Governess!—Mistress!—

Have you cut down that wood, Sir?—Oh, dear! That puts me in mind—I declare, Sir Solomon, I had quite forgot—There is a stranger now at the Castle, who can very likely give us intelligence about my father. He told me he was his friend; and he is such a kind, tender heart∣ed creature!—We'll go there first—Come.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid.
SP.P: Albina!
Miss Mandeville!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: There, Madam, read that letter; and if you wish to avoid the most exemplary punishment, look out all Mandeville's letters, and bring them to my house directly.—You, also, Sir, bring your keys and papers at the same time!—Go this moment; and while Albina's at the Castle, I'll wait your coming.
Sir Solomon!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: No reply, Sir!

If I'm to lose my place, I hope I'm not to lose my money!—There's Mr. Mandeville's debt, two year's sa∣lary, and a trifle due from Mr. Howard for the Bristol wa∣ters.—He coughed me out of à dose of physic worth thirty pounds, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: No trifling!—Begone, Sir!—Mrs. Rigid, you know my determination.

Stay!—This is the last time I shall ever see her; and I can't bear to leave her so unhappy.—Governess, though I'm a much greater object of pity than you are, yet
if my father will forgive you, I'm sure I will.—At all events, while I have money, you shan't want.—Adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rigid. [Weeping.]
SP.P: Farewell!

Psha! what signifies crying?—You see I'm not affected!—Nothing ever excites my sensibility but the touch of a guinea; and, thanks to my stewardship and the annuity trade! I've saved enough to retire and live as a gentleman ought to do.—And so, with many thanks for favours past, your servant, young lady and old gentleman!—Come along, Governess! I shall want a house keeper; and since you can't be my mistress, I'll be your master!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Ah, you two hypocrites! begone!—Oh, So∣lomon, Solomon, you ought to have known that a woman was at the bottom of all this mischief.—Come! I'll see you to the Castle, and then—
I say, Sir Solomon, if we meet Mr. Howard by the way, I hope you won't let him kill me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Kill you!—Why?
I know he'll be monstrous desperate!—In a good cause I've a good heart; but, in a bad one—Oh, Lord!—Deborah is a lion to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Never fear: I'll stand by you.—And to prove I can be a protector, without being a poacher, I'll not ask even a kiss, till I have delivered you safe into your father's hands!—No!—And then I won't trouble you, unless you particularly desire it—Come—I've given all that up for life; and I shall die as I have lived, a bachelor!
Don't! I hate bachelors—I wish there was a tax upon them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: There ought; for 'tis a luxury, I promise you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—The Baron's Chamber. Table remaining, with Pistol, &c.

SP.P:
Not here, either!—No where to be found!—What can have become of him?—Veritas detained me longer than I intended; and when I returned to the ru∣ins, Mandeville was gone; thinking, no doubt, that, like the rest of his unfeeling friends, I had forgotten and de∣serted
him! I am the most unhappy fellow living!— Sits, his hand accidentally falls on the pistol] What's here?—A pistol!—Oh, Heaven!—He couldn't be so desperate! How! the initials of his name upon the barrel! It is too evident—he has destroyed himself, and died, suspecting Howard of ingratitude! I shall not long survive him!—Oh, Mandeville! Mandeville!
Howard! Howard!
What voice is that? Speak!
'Tis I—'tis your friend!
He is living! [tries the door.] Nay: if 'twere adamant, I'd split it into atoms!
My dear fellow! The next time you kill yourself, don't leave your instrument of death behind you. The initials on this barrel make the worst Mementy mori I ever read.
Kill myself! How you misconceive, my friend! I took refuge here to avoid Realize; and meeting young Herbert, he protected me, and locked me in that apart∣ment.
Did he? Did Bobadil protect you?
He was most kind to me; and promised to make Albina kind to me. I wonder he's not returned; 'tis a long time since he left me.

Oh! he has a very slippery memory!—The young coxcomb promised to make Albina kind to me; and I've never seen nor heard of him since. However, to shew you how very likely he is to keep his word with ei∣ther of us. Albina by this time has left the Castle, and gone to Dover.
Gone to Dover!
I saw the carriage at the door an hour ago. 'Sdeath! it's only lost time to think of her or Horbert! So, let us go to London—let us escape while we can.

Well, be it so. 'Tis plain I am forgotten—and therefore I, like Albina, will bid adieu to the Castle for ever. And while she hurries to scenes of gaiety and hap∣piness, her father shall—No: while I have your friend∣ship, Howard, I ought, and will defy misfortune. [Noise
of door opening.] We are interrupted: set us return to the chamber.

STAGE.HI: [Exeunt at the door Mandeville came from.]

SP.P: Oh, dear! I'm such a coward!—Coming up stairs, I thought I heard Mr. Howard's voice in this room; and I dread his reproaches, and his triumph, and his anger so much, that I'd rather see the old Baron himself—Oh! it's all fancy—He's not here! So I may open the door, and venture to talk to my prisoner—Heigho! the sight of peo∣ple one has injured is so dreadful, that I do believe, if Mr. Howard—
Holloa! What's the matter?
Nothing: I'm better now: I thought—
Well: what did you think?
I thought you had been the old Baron—But, I see—I see [Stealing away from him by degrees.] Good bye, Mr. Howard.
Your servant.
There! I said so. I knew he'd be desperate. Good bye Sir; I'm going!—Don't you see I'm going?
Going!—Why ar'n't you gone?
So I am—I am gone. Nay: you needn't be quite in such a hurry, Sir.
I am in a hurry. I can't waste my time on doll and kickshaws.

Oh! I was sure this would be the case!—What shall I do? I've a great mind to take courage—to sum∣mon up all my resolution, and go boldly within ten yards of him. [She advances, Howard turns, and frowns at her—She is frightened, and stops. He turns his back again, and she goes nearer to him.] Lord! he takes it very quietly—I'll go closer. So—I dare say if I were to touch him he wouldn't bite my head off. Mr. Howard! How d'ye do, Mr. Howard?
Keep off! or—

Indeed I'm very sorry—I know I've behaved very
ill; but it was the Governess's fault, and not mine. Pray now forgive me—Look—on my knees I entreat you!—Forgive me this once, and I'll be such a good, dear, dar∣ling girl!—I'll be your slave—your doll—your kick— [Howard smiles, and Albina jumps up.] Oh, he smiles!—Your're a good natured creature, Howard! ha! ha!
I don't smile.
You do! you do!
I say I don't!—And hark'ye, if I were weak enough to forgive you on my own account—how—how would you apologize for your unnatural conduct to your father?
I'll shew you—Look—

STAGE.HI: [Takes a paper out of her pocket]

SP.P: What's that paper?
My grandfather's will!—Look!
What!—Do you make a display—Do you boast of your ill-gotten wealth? Hear me! [Lays hold of her hand ith great emotion] The Tutor has confessed—
I know it.
That Mr. Mandeville—that my friend—remit∣ted money from India—
I know it.
That the Governess—that your friend—con∣cealed his letters—
I know it.

Then how dare you insult me with this ill∣timed triumph? One word more, and we part for ever!—No chuckling!—Listen! [Taking her hand with great vio∣lence.] If your grandfather had known these facts, would he have disinherited an affectionate son, only to adopt an unfeeling daughter? Would he not have destroyed that testament?

To be sure he would! And as he can't do it him∣self, won't I do it for him? There—and there—and there — [tearing the Will.] I'm my own mistress now; and I think I can't do greater honour to my grandfather's memory, than by destroying an instrument that he would now blush to sign, and I for ever be ashamed to profit by!
Are you—How handsome she looks!—Are you convinced?

I am: I hate my Governess as much for her un∣ceasing enmity to my father, as I envy you for your exalted friendship towards him!—Oh, Mr. Howard! Do you think he'll ever forgive me?—I'm going in search of him; but if you should be so fortunate as to see him before me, pray tell him that things are now what they ought al∣ways to have been—He is the possessor of the Mande∣ville estate, and I have nothing but what results from his bounty. Farewell!

Stay: it's my turn to kneel now! [Kneels.] Oh! you angel! [Rises.] Mandeville! Come forth, Mandeville. There is no longer any cause for concealing yourself! Enter MANDEVILLE. Look at her! Look at Albina, your much-abused daughter! She has parted from her Governess! She has torn her Grandfather's will! She has—Damn it! why don't you speak to her? Joy choaks me! I'm dumb!
My child! My child!
My father!
Have I at length a recompense? Oh, Howard! Did I not say the time would come?—
Why will you speak to me, when you know I can't answer you?
Will you forgive me, Sir? Can you forget—

Forget! I never blamed you. And at this mo∣ment your mother's virtues shine out so brightly in your conduct, that I could wish that Will were still in force. I want not now my father's wealth to make me happy—My child, my long-lost daughter is restored to me, and I am blest, and rich beyond my hopes!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir SOLOMON, COPSLEY, and CICELY.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Come, Albina! 'Tis time to proceed on our journey. What, Mandeville! Howard! all together! all reconciled!—Tol de rol lol!
So you're come to play the governor!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P:
Not I. I've been as great a fool as any of you. I thought Mrs. Rigid a divinity, but I've found out she's
a woman! Veritas has convented me. I'm a fair penitent now. Howard! Mandeville, you have deserved better treatment;—give me your hand.—George, give me yours.—And now, my little fellow-traveller, give me the kiss we talked of.—No: hang it! 'twill be only distressing you!
Nay, Sir Solomon, if it will give you any pleasure, I'm sure it will give me no pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Arch rogue! Now I'll take it by proxy, on pur∣pose to be revenged. There, George, try how you can bear it [Howard kisses Albina]. So, does it give you much pain? Well, what say you. Mr. Mandeville?—How shall we punish these two culprits? Shall we inflict matrimony, or separation?
Oh! Matrimony, by all means! Don't you think so, Sir?
I do, indeed! The day that gives Albina such a husband, and makes me father of such a son as Howard, must be the proudest and happiest of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Say you so? Then take her George! And if the marriage state can afford happiness—However, we won't talk of impossibilities.
Now, Albina, will you ever talk of Cicely again?
Will you ever call me Becky again?
Becky!
If you do, I'll make you a companion to the wild goose in the cottage. "I hope your lungs are better, Sir?"

STAGE.HI: [Reminding him by her voice and attitude.]

SP.P: What! Were you Bobadil? Were you the little smart, well-made Lieutenant?
I was young Herbert, Sir; and I bless the disguise, not only for convincing me of the sincerity of my lover, but also for introducing me to my father. I hope you don't blame me. Sir?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: He blame you! No: Howard has most reason. What will your husband say to your strutting about in boy's clothes?
Say! That I wish all women would wear the breeches before marriage, instead of afterwards.
Oh, Madam! How shall I thank you? You have saved me and my family from ruin.
You have, Madam! and we are all gratitude.
This is your benefactor; you are to thank my fa∣ther, not me. If you wish to do me a favour—why, there is one—
Oh, name it, Madam! name it!

Why it rather concerns Sir Solomon than myself. Pray be kind enough to have the old curtain repaired, left he should again wish to take cover behind it. And like∣wise, to send me some of the straw—I mean to be married in a straw hat—and I'll have one manufactured out of Sir Solomon's stubble!
One! We'll have a dozen! And our children shall wear them, in honour of their great uncle's gallantry!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.P: Gallantry! Pshal I've something better to think of than women.

Indeed you have not. Come, come, Uncle—Rail at the sex as much as you like, you must confess, that life is a blank without them; and the gaming-table, the bottle, and the sports of the field, are all so many substitutes—shadows!—Woman is the true substance, after all—And, compared to her, all other objects are as the glow worm to the sun! It may dazzle the fight—but it can never warm the heart! Don't you think so, Albina.

I do, indeed. Women are certainly most superior creatures; and, if by accident they have any faults, men ought not to see them—At least, I hope that will be my case to night. I have done and talked a great many foo∣lish things: but having their hands, and full pardon [Standing between Mandeville and Howard]; let me have yours—and Albina will be the happiest of wives, and the most grateful of daughters.

BYLINE.HI: Written by M. P. ANDREWS, Esq

LG.L: THE World's a Stage—and Man has Seven Ages

So Shakespeare writesThe idea of this parody of the Seven Ages of Shakespeare, was suggested to Mr. Reynolds by his friend Mr. Rogers (Author of The Pleasures to Memory), and the lines printed in Italies were furaished by him.—King of Dramatic Sages;
But he forgot to tell you in his plan,
That Woman plays her part as well as Man.

L.HI: First, how her infant heart with triumph swells,

LG.L: When the red coral shakes its silver hells!—
She, like young Stotesen, as the rattle rings,
Leaps at the sound, and strum in leading-strings.
Next, little Miss, in pin-a-fore so trim,
With nurse so noisy—with mama so prim—
Eager to tell you all she's taught to utter—
Lisps as the grasps the allotted bread and butter;
Type of her sex—who, though no longer young,
Hold every thing with ease—except their tongue.

L.HI: A School-girl then—She curls her hair in papers,
And mimics Father's gout, and Mother's vapours;
Tramples alike on customs, and on toes,
And whispers all she hears, to all she knows:

LG.L: "Betty!" she cries, "it comes into my head,
"Old maids grow cross because their cats are dead;
"My Governess has been in such a fuss
"About the death of our old tabby puss—
"She wears black stockings—Ha! ha!—What a "pother,
"'Cause one old cat's in mourning for another!"
The Child of Nature—free from pride and pomp,
And sure to please, though nothing but a Romp!
Next riper Miss, who, Nature more disclosing,
Now finds some traits of art are interposing;

L.HI: And with blue laughing eyes behind her fan,
First acts her part—with that great actor, Man!

LG.L: Behold her now an ogling, vain Coquette,
Catching male gudgeons in her silver'd net:
All things revers'd—the neck, cropt close and bare,
Scarce feels th' incumbrance of a single hair;
Whilst the thick forehead tresses, frizzled full,
Rival the tufted locks that grace the bull.—

L.HI: Then comes that sober character—a Wife,
With all the dear, distracting cares of life;

LG.L: A thousand cards, a thousand joys extend,
For what may not upon a card depend?
Though Justice in the morn claim fifty pounds,
Five hundre won at night may heal the wounds!—

L.HI: Now she'll snatch half a glance at Opera, Ball,
A meteor trac'd by none, though seen by all;

LG.L: Till Spousy finds, while anxious to immure her,
A Patent Coffin only can secure her!

L.HI: At last the Dowager—in ancient flounces,

LG.L: With snuff and spectacles, this age denounces—
And thus she moralizes— [Speaks like an old woman.]
"How bold and forward each young flirt appears!
"Courtship, in my time, lasted seven years—
"Now seven little months suffice of course,
"For courting, marrying, scolding, and divorce!
"What with their truss'd-up shapes and pantaloons,
"Dress occupies the whole of honey-moons;—
"They say we have no souls—but what more odd is,
"Nor men, nor women now have any bodies!—
"When I was young—my heart was always tender,
"And would, to every spouse I had, surrender;
"Their wishes to refuse I never durst—
"And my fourth died as happy as my first."
Truce to such splenetic and rash designs,
And let us mingle candour with our lines.
In all the stages of domestic life,
As child, as sifter, parent friend, and wife,
Woman, the source of every sond employ,
Softens affliction; and enlivens joy.
What is your boast, male rulers of the land?
How cold and cheerless all you can command!
Vain your ambition—vain your wealth and power.
Unless kind woman share your raptur'd hour;
Unless, 'midst all the glare of pageant art,
She adds her smile, and triumphs in your heart.
